author: John (Ἰωάννης / Yohanan — 'God is gracious'), son of Zebedee, one of the twelve apostles. Called 'the disciple whom Jesus loved.' Wrote this gospel late in life, likely from Ephesus around 85-95 AD — decades after Matthew, Mark, and Luke. By this time, the Temple had been destroyed (70 AD), Christianity had separated from Judaism, and Greek philosophical concepts like Logos were common in the culture John was writing to.
audience: Written primarily to Greek-speaking believers and seekers in Asia Minor (modern Turkey). Unlike Matthew (written for Jews) or Luke (written for Romans), John writes for people familiar with Greek philosophical concepts. This is why he opens with 'Logos' — a term Greek philosophers had debated for 600 years. He's meeting his audience where they are and saying 'that thing you've been searching for? He has a name.'
historicalContext: By the time John writes, the other three gospels have been circulating for 20-30 years. John doesn't repeat their material much — he includes things they left out and goes deeper theologically. The early church father Clement of Alexandria called John 'the spiritual gospel.' Rome has destroyed Jerusalem. Christians are being persecuted. Gnostic heresies are emerging — groups claiming Jesus wasn't truly human, or that the physical world is evil. John writes to counter these directly: 'The Word became FLESH' (1:14) is a direct shot at Gnosticism.

verses.verseText: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
verses.freshTranslation: In the origin of all things, the Word already existed. The Word was face-to-face with God, and the Word was Himself God.
verses.historicalContext: John deliberately echoes Genesis 1:1 — 'In the beginning God created...' (בְּרֵאשִׁית בָּרָא אֱלֹהִים / Bereshit bara Elohim). His Greek audience would immediately recognize 'Logos' from Heraclitus and Stoic philosophy — the rational principle behind the universe. His Jewish audience would hear Genesis. John is saying: the Logos the Greeks have been theorizing about and the Creator God of Genesis are the same being.

crossRefs.explanation: Identical opening phrase. John is declaring that Jesus (the Word) was present at creation — not created, but the Creator.
Wisdom personified, existing before creation: 'Before the mountains were settled, before the hills, I was brought forth.' Early church saw this as a picture of Christ.
Paul confirms: 'By Him all things were created... He is before all things, and in Him all things hold together.'
Jesus returns and 'His name is called The Word of God' — the same title John uses here, bookending the entire New Testament.

words.literalMeaning: in, within, among
words.definition: A primary preposition denoting position — being inside or within something. Here it marks a point in time, but with deeper implications: the Word wasn't just AT the beginning, He was IN it — embedded in the very fabric of origin.
words.translationNote: Translated accurately. No issues here.

words.literalMeaning: beginning, origin, first cause, ruling principle
words.definition: From archō — to be first, to rule. This word means far more than just 'starting point.' It carries the idea of ORIGIN, FIRST CAUSE, and RULING AUTHORITY. It's where we get words like 'architect' (master builder), 'archetype' (original pattern), 'monarchy' (one ruler). When John says 'in the archē,' he's not just saying 'a long time ago.' He's saying 'in the foundational origin of everything that exists — the first cause behind all causes — the Word was already there.'
words.translationNote: Translated as 'beginning' which captures the temporal sense but loses the deeper meaning of 'origin' and 'first cause.' The word implies authority and primacy, not just chronology.

words.partOfSpeech: verb, imperfect active indicative, 3rd person singular
words.literalMeaning: was existing, was being
words.definition: Imperfect tense of eimi (to be). This is CRITICAL. The imperfect tense in Greek means continuous action in the past — 'was already existing' or 'was continually being.' It does NOT mean 'came into being' or 'was created.' John uses a completely different word later (egeneto — 'came into being') for created things. The Word didn't come into existence at the beginning. The Word WAS ALREADY EXISTING when the beginning happened. This is John's way of saying the Word is eternal — predating creation itself.
words.translationNote: English 'was' technically works but loses the continuous/pre-existing force of the Greek imperfect. A more precise translation would be 'was already in existence' or 'was continually existing.'

words.partOfSpeech: noun, nominative masculine singular with article
words.literalMeaning: word, speech, reason, rational principle, divine expression, the totality of God's self-revelation
words.definition: This is one of the richest words in all of Greek. Logos had been debated by philosophers for 600 years before John used it. Heraclitus (500 BC) used logos to describe the rational principle governing the universe — the invisible logic behind everything. The Stoics made it central to their philosophy — the divine reason permeating all reality. Jewish philosopher Philo of Alexandria used logos as the bridge between the transcendent God and the physical world. John takes ALL of these threads and drops a bomb: the Logos isn't an abstract principle. It's a PERSON. He walks, talks, bleeds, and has a name. John essentially says: 'That rational principle behind the universe that you philosophers have been theorizing about for six centuries? I had dinner with Him.'
words.translationNote: 'Word' is the standard translation but it's severely limiting. In English, 'word' is just a unit of speech. Logos encompasses reason, logic, divine expression, creative power, the ordering principle of existence. There's no single English word that captures it. 'Word' was chosen because of the connection to God speaking creation into existence (Genesis 1 — 'God SAID let there be light'), but it loses the philosophical and cosmic dimensions.
words.twistedExplanation: Not twisted intentionally, but 'Word' domesticates logos. Most English readers think 'word' = something you say. Logos means the rational, creative, self-revealing expression of God Himself — His mind made manifest. Every time you read 'the Word' in John, mentally replace it with 'the full expression of everything God is.'

words.literalMeaning: and, also, even
words.definition: Standard conjunction connecting clauses.
words.translationNote: Accurate.

words.original: ὁ λόγος ἦν πρὸς τὸν θεόν
words.transliteration: ho logos ēn pros ton theon
words.pronunciation: ho LOH-gos ayn pros ton theh-ON
words.literalMeaning: the Word was toward/facing God
words.definition: The preposition πρός (pros) with the accusative case doesn't just mean 'with' in the sense of 'near' or 'alongside.' It means 'toward, face-to-face with, in active relationship with.' It implies movement, intimacy, dynamic interaction. The Word wasn't just next to God like a book on a shelf. The Word was FACING God — in eternal, intimate, face-to-face communion. This is John's first hint at the Trinity: the Word is distinct from God (face-to-face implies two parties) yet equal (you don't stand face-to-face with someone infinitely above you).
words.translationNote: 'With' is technically acceptable but loses the face-to-face intimacy. 'With' in English can mean 'I was with 10,000 people at a concert.' Pros means 'I was facing you, in direct personal relationship.' The difference matters enormously.

words.literalMeaning: and God was the Word
words.definition: Notice the Greek word order: theos (God) comes FIRST for emphasis. There's no definite article before theos here — it's 'theos' not 'ho theos.' In Greek grammar, this is called a predicate nominative without the article, which emphasizes the NATURE or QUALITY of the subject. John is saying the Word has the nature/essence of God — the Word is fully divine. This is not saying 'the Word was A god' (which would require the indefinite article, which Greek doesn't have, but would use different construction). This is also not saying 'the Word was THE God' (which would collapse the distinction established in the previous clause). It's saying: the Word possesses the full nature of deity. Distinct person. Same essence.
words.translationNote: English 'the Word was God' is accurate but the emphasis is lost. In Greek, putting theos first is like saying 'GOD — that's what the Word was.' The emphasis lands on the divine nature.
words.twistedExplanation: Jehovah's Witnesses translate this as 'the Word was a god' in their New World Translation, arguing the lack of article before theos means it's indefinite. This is grammatically incorrect — Colwell's Rule in Greek grammar shows that predicate nominatives before the verb are typically anarthrous (without article) without being indefinite. Nearly every Greek scholar — secular and religious — rejects the JW translation. The grammar is clear: the Word is fully God in nature.

verses.verseText: He was in the beginning with God.
verses.freshTranslation: This one — He was already there, face-to-face with God, from the very origin.
verses.historicalContext: John repeats himself. In Hebrew literary tradition, repetition means emphasis — 'pay attention, this matters.' He's making absolutely sure you understand: the Word is eternal, the Word is with God, the Word is God. Three truths, stated twice. No ambiguity allowed.

crossRefs.explanation: 'His origins are from old, from ancient days' (מִימֵי עוֹלָם / mimei olam) — the Messiah's origins stretch back to eternity.
Jesus prays: 'Glorify me with the glory I had with you BEFORE THE WORLD EXISTED.' He claims pre-existence directly.

words.literalMeaning: this one, this same one
words.definition: A demonstrative pronoun meaning 'this one' — pointing emphatically. John isn't just saying 'he.' He's saying 'THIS ONE — this specific one I just told you about — the Logos.' It's a finger pointing at the subject: THAT one. Him. The Word. In case you were confused about who I'm talking about.
words.translationNote: 'He' works but loses the emphatic, pointing quality. 'This one' would be more accurate.

words.literalMeaning: was existing continually
words.definition: Same imperfect tense as verse 1 — continuous pre-existence. John keeps using ēn (was already existing) for the Word. He'll switch to egeneto (came into being) when talking about creation in verse 3. The contrast is intentional and devastating: everything else CAME INTO BEING. The Word simply WAS.
words.translationNote: Same note as verse 1 — English 'was' technically works but doesn't convey the ongoing, pre-existent force.

words.literalMeaning: in the origin/first cause
words.definition: Repeated from verse 1 for emphasis.
words.translationNote: See verse 1 notes.

words.literalMeaning: toward God, face-to-face with God
words.definition: Same phrase as verse 1 — pros with accusative = face-to-face intimate relationship. Repeated for emphasis.
words.translationNote: See verse 1 notes on pros.

verses.verseText: All things were made through Him, and without Him nothing was made that was made.
verses.freshTranslation: Everything that exists came into being through Him. Not a single thing that has come into existence came into existence apart from Him.
verses.historicalContext: This is John's creation statement — and it directly challenges both Greek and Gnostic thinking. Greek philosophy held that the material world was inferior or even evil, created by a lesser being (a 'demiurge'). Gnosticism (which was emerging as John wrote) taught that the physical world was a mistake or a prison. John says NO — the physical world was created by the Logos, who IS God. Matter isn't evil. Creation isn't a mistake. Everything that exists was intentionally made by the same Word who is face-to-face with God.

crossRefs.explanation: 'God SAID let there be light.' How did God create? By SPEAKING. His Word — His Logos — was the instrument of creation. John is identifying Jesus as the voice that spoke the universe into existence.
'For by Him all things were created, in heaven and on earth, visible and invisible, whether thrones or dominions or rulers or authorities — all things were created through Him and for Him.'
'Through whom He also created the worlds' — the Son as agent of creation is consistent across NT authors.
'By the word (דְּבַר / davar) of the Lord the heavens were made.' The OT already attributed creation to God's Word.

words.literalMeaning: all, every, the whole, everything without exception
words.definition: Panta — every single thing. No exceptions. John uses the most absolute, comprehensive word available. Not 'many things' or 'most things.' EVERYTHING. This word leaves zero room for the Word Himself to be a created being. If ALL things that were made were made through Him, He cannot be something that was made.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. 'All things' captures panta well.

words.partOfSpeech: verb, aorist middle indicative, 3rd person singular
words.literalMeaning: came into being, came into existence, was generated
words.definition: HERE IT IS. This is the word John has been saving. For the Word, he used ēn — 'was already existing.' For creation, he switches to egeneto — 'came into being.' These are two fundamentally different verbs. ēn = eternal, continuous existence. egeneto = a point in time when something that didn't exist began to exist. The Word WAS (ēn). Everything else BECAME (egeneto). That verb switch is John's entire theology of Christ in two words. The Word never 'became' — He always 'was.' Everything else had a moment of becoming.
words.translationNote: 'Were made' works but obscures the critical verb change. 'Came into being' is more precise and shows the contrast with ēn (was) used for the Word.

words.literalMeaning: through Him, by means of Him, via Him
words.definition: Dia with genitive = through, by means of, as the agent or instrument. The Word is the agent through whom creation happened. God the Father willed it. The Word executed it. This is the division of roles within the Trinity — the Father purposes, the Son enacts, the Spirit empowers. When Genesis says 'God said,' the 'saying' IS the Logos.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.literalMeaning: and apart from Him, and separate from Him
words.definition: Chōris — apart from, without, separate from. John states the positive (all through Him) then restates the negative (nothing apart from Him). This is a Hebrew rhetorical device called 'synthetic parallelism' — saying the same thing from two angles to make it airtight. No loopholes. Nothing slips through. If it exists, He made it.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.literalMeaning: not even one thing
words.definition: Oude hen — literally 'not even one.' Not 'nothing' in a vague sense. Not even ONE thing. John is being mathematically precise. The count of things that exist apart from the Word's creative power is exactly zero.
words.translationNote: 'Nothing' captures it but 'not even one thing' is more emphatic in the Greek.

words.partOfSpeech: verb aorist + relative pronoun + verb perfect
words.literalMeaning: came into being that has come into being
words.definition: Notice the tense shift: egeneto (aorist — point in time) and gegonen (perfect — completed action with ongoing results). Everything that came into being at a point in time and continues to exist in its created state — ALL of it came through the Word. The perfect tense (gegonen) emphasizes that creation isn't just a past event. It's a completed act with present, ongoing reality. What the Word made still stands. It endures.
words.translationNote: English repetition 'was made that was made' sounds awkward but actually reflects the Greek construction. Some translations try to smooth it out and lose the emphasis.

verses.verseText: In Him was life, and the life was the light of men.
verses.freshTranslation: Within Him was life itself — the animating force of existence — and that life was the illumination of humanity.
verses.historicalContext: John introduces two of his key themes that will run through the entire gospel: life (zoē) and light (phōs). These aren't metaphors at this point — they're ontological statements. The Word doesn't just HAVE life. Life exists IN Him. He is the source, not a recipient. This directly challenges the Greek philosophical view that life emerged from impersonal processes. John says life has a personal source: the Logos.

crossRefs.explanation: God breathed the breath of LIFE (נִשְׁמַת חַיִּים / nishmat chayyim) into Adam. The source of biological life is God's own breath — His ruach. John is connecting the Logos to that same life-giving power.
Jesus later says 'I am the way, the truth, and the LIFE.' Not 'I show you life' or 'I give life.' I AM life. John 1:4 is the theological foundation for that claim.
'For with You is the fountain of life; in Your LIGHT we see light.' David connected life and light to God 1,000 years before John wrote this.
John writes later: 'God IS light, and in Him is no darkness at all.' Same author, same theology — light isn't something God produces, it's what He IS.

words.literalMeaning: within Him, inside Him
words.definition: En — within, inside. Not 'with Him' or 'near Him.' INSIDE Him. Life doesn't exist alongside the Word. It exists WITHIN Him. He is the container, the source, the wellspring. Everything alive draws its life from what's inside the Logos.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.literalMeaning: was continually existing
words.definition: Again ēn — the imperfect. Life was CONTINUALLY in Him. Not temporarily. Not granted then revoked. Permanently, endlessly, inherently. Life is native to the Logos.
words.translationNote: See verse 1.

words.literalMeaning: life, the principle of life, vitality, the absolute fullness of life
words.definition: Greek has two words for life: bios (βίος) and zoē (ζωή). Bios is biological life — duration, physical existence, the mechanics of being alive. It's where we get 'biology.' Zoē is something deeper — the animating principle, the quality of aliveness, life in its fullest and most vibrant sense. It's where we get 'zoology.' When John says the Word had ZOĒ, he's not saying the Word had a pulse. He's saying the Word contained the very essence of what it means to be alive. Every living thing — from bacteria to angels — derives its aliveness from the zoē that exists in the Logos. Jesus later uses this word when He says 'I came that they may have LIFE (zoē) and have it abundantly' (John 10:10). He's not offering longer bios. He's offering a different quality of existence entirely.
words.translationNote: 'Life' is accurate but English doesn't distinguish between bios and zoē. When you read 'life' in John's gospel, it's almost always zoē — the deep, essential, God-sourced kind, not just breathing.

words.literalMeaning: and the life (that specific life just mentioned)
words.definition: The article 'hē' (the) is important — it's pointing back to the specific life just mentioned. THE life that's in the Word — that particular life — is now going to be identified as something else. John is building a chain: Word → life → light. Each link reveals more about what the Logos is.
words.translationNote: Accurate.

words.literalMeaning: was continually the light/illumination
words.definition: Phōs — light, radiance, illumination. Not just physical light but understanding, revelation, truth made visible. In the ancient world, light was synonymous with knowledge and truth. Darkness was ignorance and evil. John is saying: the life that's in the Logos — that fundamental aliveness — IS the thing that illuminates humanity. It's what lets us see truth, understand meaning, perceive reality. Without the Logos, humanity is in the dark — not just morally but existentially. We wouldn't even have consciousness (the hard problem you and I discussed) without the light that comes from the life that comes from the Word.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. Phōs is well-served by 'light' in English since we use light metaphorically for understanding too.

words.partOfSpeech: noun, genitive masculine plural with article
words.literalMeaning: of humans, of mankind
words.definition: Anthrōpos — a human being, regardless of gender. This is generic humanity, not males specifically (that would be anēr/andros). The life in the Logos illuminates ALL humans. This is universal — not just Jews, not just believers, not just the elect. Every human being who has ever lived has been touched by this light. John will develop this in verse 9: the true light 'enlightens EVERY person.' This means the image of God in you, your conscience, your sense of right and wrong, your capacity to perceive beauty and truth — all of it comes from the Logos. Even people who never hear the gospel have been lit by this light.
words.translationNote: Modern translations often render this 'of people' or 'of humanity' instead of 'of men' to reflect that anthrōpos is gender-inclusive. 'Of men' in older translations isn't wrong but can sound male-specific to modern ears.

verses.verseText: And the light shines in the darkness, and the darkness did not comprehend it.
verses.freshTranslation: And the light keeps shining in the darkness, and the darkness has never been able to overpower it — or even understand it.
verses.historicalContext: John shifts to present tense — 'shines' not 'shone.' The light isn't a past event. It's ongoing. Right now. And notice he doesn't say darkness 'fought' the light or 'attacked' the light. He uses a word that means both 'comprehend' and 'overcome' — the darkness can neither understand the light nor defeat it. For John's audience living under Roman persecution, this was a statement of defiance: the empire, the darkness, the evil — it can't even grasp what it's fighting against, let alone win.

crossRefs.explanation: 'Darkness was over the face of the deep... and God said let there be light.' The first act of creation was light invading darkness. John is saying the same thing is still happening.
'The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light.' Messianic prophecy — the light entering human darkness.
Jesus later says: 'Light has come into the world, and people loved the darkness rather than the light because their works were evil.' The rejection is willful, not intellectual.

words.literalMeaning: and the light
words.definition: Same phōs from verse 4, now becoming the subject. The light that IS the life that IS in the Word — that light is about to be described in action.
words.translationNote: Accurate.

words.partOfSpeech: verb, present active indicative, 3rd person singular
words.literalMeaning: shines, appears, gives light, makes visible
words.definition: Present tense — this is happening NOW. Not 'shone' (past). The light IS shining. John switches from imperfect (ēn — was) to present (phainei — shines) to make a point: everything he said about the Word in verses 1-4 is past. But the light shining in darkness? That's present reality. It's still happening as you read this. The root phaino means 'to make visible, to bring to appearance.' It's where we get 'phenomenon' and 'epiphany.' The light doesn't just glow passively — it actively makes things visible that were hidden in darkness.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. The present tense is preserved in English 'shines.'

words.literalMeaning: in the darkness, within the darkness
words.definition: Skotia — darkness, gloom, obscurity. Related to skotos (σκότος). In John's theology, darkness isn't just absence of light — it's a moral and spiritual condition. It's the state of being disconnected from the Logos. Ignorance, evil, death, separation from God — all wrapped in one word. And the light shines IN it — not next to it, not above it, not avoiding it. In it. The light goes into the darkest places. It doesn't wait for darkness to come to it.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.partOfSpeech: negative particle + verb, aorist active indicative
words.literalMeaning: did not seize/grasp/overtake/comprehend
words.definition: THIS is one of the most brilliant word choices in the entire Bible. Katalambanō has TWO meanings that BOTH apply: (1) to comprehend, understand, grasp mentally — the darkness doesn't UNDERSTAND the light; (2) to seize, overtake, overcome — the darkness can't DEFEAT the light. John is using a deliberate double meaning. The darkness is both intellectually baffled by the light AND powerless to extinguish it. It can't figure it out, and it can't shut it down. Both meanings are true simultaneously. This is literary genius — one word carrying two complete theological statements.
words.translationNote: This is where translations REALLY differ and none of them get it fully right. KJV: 'comprehended it not' (gets meaning 1). NIV: 'has not overcome it' (gets meaning 2). Both are half right. The Greek carries both meanings at once. No single English word captures the double meaning of katalambanō. 'Did not comprehend it' loses the 'overcome' sense. 'Did not overcome it' loses the 'understand' sense. A truly honest translation would need a footnote: 'The darkness neither understood nor overpowered the light.'
words.twistedExplanation: Every English translation is forced to pick one meaning of katalambanō and lose the other. This is a genuine limitation of translation, not a deliberate twisting — but readers should know they're only getting half the meaning in any single English rendering. The double meaning is John's entire point: darkness is both ignorant of and impotent against the light.

verses.verseText: There was a man sent from God, whose name was John.
verses.freshTranslation: There came into being a man, commissioned by God — his name was John.
verses.historicalContext: After five verses of cosmic theology — the eternal Logos, creation, life, light — John suddenly drops to ground level. A man. Sent from God. Named John. This is John the Baptist (not the author). The shift from cosmic to human is intentional — it mirrors what's about to happen in verse 14 when the Word becomes flesh. God works through real people in real history, not just abstract principles. John the Baptist was a priest's son (Luke 1:5), lived in the wilderness, wore camel hair, ate locusts. He was the last Old Testament-style prophet and the bridge to the New.

crossRefs.explanation: 'Behold, I send my messenger, and he will prepare the way before me.' Written 400+ years before John the Baptist was born. The last verse of the last OT prophet predicted the first person introduced in this gospel.
'A voice crying in the wilderness: Prepare the way of the Lord.' John the Baptist quotes this about himself (John 1:23).
The angel Gabriel announced John's birth to his father Zechariah, saying he would go before the Lord 'in the spirit and power of Elijah.'

words.partOfSpeech: verb, aorist middle indicative, 3rd person singular
words.literalMeaning: came into being, came into existence
words.definition: HERE is the verb switch again. For the Word, John used ēn — 'was already existing.' For John the Baptist, he uses egeneto — 'came into being.' The Baptist had a beginning. The Word did not. Even John's grammar preaches theology. Every created being egeneto. Only the Logos ēn.
words.translationNote: 'There was' completely hides the verb change from ēn to egeneto. A reader of the English would never know John switched verbs. 'There came into being' would preserve the contrast.
words.twistedExplanation: Not deliberately twisted, but the English flattens a critical distinction. In Greek, the difference between ēn (verses 1-2) and egeneto (verse 6) is the difference between eternal existence and created existence. English 'was' hides this entirely.

words.literalMeaning: a human being, a person
words.definition: After five verses about the divine Logos, John introduces a human. Just anthrōpos — a man. Not an angel, not a heavenly being. A regular human person. The contrast is intentional: the Logos is eternal God; John is a created man. But this created man has a divine commission. God uses ordinary people for extraordinary purposes.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.partOfSpeech: verb, perfect passive participle, nominative masculine singular
words.literalMeaning: having been sent, commissioned, dispatched on a mission
words.definition: From apostellō — to send out on a mission with authority. This is the root of 'apostle' (apostolos). The perfect tense means the sending happened in the past but the commission is still active — John was sent and REMAINS sent. The passive voice means he didn't send himself — he was sent BY someone. This is a divine commission, not self-appointment. Every true prophet is apestalmenos — sent by God, not self-promoting.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated, though 'sent' doesn't fully convey the perfect tense — he was sent and his mission continues.

words.literalMeaning: from beside God, from God's side, from God's presence
words.definition: Para with genitive = from beside, from the side of. John the Baptist didn't just receive orders from God at a distance. He came FROM God's side — from God's very presence. This elevates the Baptist's authority: he's not a freelance preacher with opinions. He comes directly from the throne room with a specific assignment.
words.translationNote: 'From God' is adequate but loses the 'from beside' nuance of para. He didn't just come from God generically — he came from God's presence, God's side.

words.literalMeaning: name to-him John (Yohanan — 'God is gracious')
words.definition: Iōannēs is the Greek form of the Hebrew יוֹחָנָן (Yohanan), meaning 'Yahweh is gracious' or 'God has shown grace.' His name IS his message. The last prophet before the Messiah carries a name that declares God's grace. He wasn't named 'God judges' or 'God punishes.' He was named 'God is gracious.' The forerunner of Christ arrives under the banner of grace, not law.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated, but readers miss that 'John' means something. Biblical names are almost always significant. His name declares the theme of his ministry.

verses.verseText: This man came for a witness, to bear witness of the Light, that all through him might believe.
verses.freshTranslation: This one came for the purpose of testimony — to testify about the Light — so that everyone might come to trust through him.
verses.historicalContext: John the author is writing at a time when some people were still following John the Baptist's movement rather than Jesus. There were 'disciples of John' decades after the Baptist's death (Acts 19:1-3). The author is making clear: the Baptist was not the Light. He pointed TO the Light. This clarification was necessary for his first readers.

crossRefs.explanation: Paul found disciples in Ephesus (where this gospel was written!) who only knew John's baptism, not Jesus. This is exactly the confusion the author is correcting.
Jesus later says of the Baptist: 'He was a burning and shining lamp, and you were willing to rejoice for a while in his light.' A lamp, not THE Light. Reflects, doesn't generate.

words.partOfSpeech: demonstrative pronoun + verb, aorist active indicative
words.literalMeaning: this one came, this one arrived
words.definition: Houtos — 'this one,' pointing emphatically at the Baptist. Ēlthen — from erchomai, to come. Aorist tense — a specific, decisive arrival. He didn't wander in. He arrived with purpose.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.literalMeaning: for the purpose of testimony, for witness-bearing
words.definition: Martyria — testimony, witness, evidence. This is where we get the word 'martyr.' In the early church, bearing witness (martyria) and dying for that witness became so linked that the word itself came to mean someone who dies for their faith. John the Baptist literally became a martyr — beheaded for his testimony. The word predicted his fate. His entire purpose was martyria — not to be famous, not to build a following, but to point to someone else and say 'THAT one.'
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. The martyria→martyr connection is worth knowing.

words.english: to bear witness of the Light
words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + verb subjunctive + preposition + noun genitive
words.literalMeaning: in order that he might testify about the Light
words.definition: Hina — purpose clause. 'In order that.' The Baptist's existence had a single purpose: testify about the Light. Not testify about himself, not build his own brand, not start a religion. Point. That's it. Peri tou phōtos — concerning the Light. The same phōs from verses 4-5. The Light that IS the life that IS in the Logos. The Baptist's job was to help people see what was already shining.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.english: that all through him might believe
words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + adjective + verb subjunctive + preposition + pronoun
words.literalMeaning: in order that all might trust/believe through him
words.definition: Pisteusōsin — from pisteuō, to believe, to trust, to have faith, to be persuaded. This isn't intellectual agreement ('I believe that's a chair'). It's relational trust — entrusting yourself to someone. And pantes — ALL. Not 'some.' Not 'the elect.' ALL might believe. The Baptist's testimony was aimed at everyone. The scope of the invitation is universal even if the response isn't.
words.translationNote: 'Believe' in modern English has weakened to mean 'think something is true.' The Greek pisteuō is much stronger — it's placing your trust in, committing yourself to, relying upon. More like 'trust' than 'believe.'
words.twistedExplanation: The word 'believe' has been so watered down in English that 'I believe in God' can mean anything from deep personal trust to casual acknowledgment. In Greek, pisteuō means putting your full weight on something — like sitting in a chair you trust will hold you. Most English readers drastically underestimate what 'believe' means in the New Testament.

verses.verseText: He was not that Light, but was sent to bear witness of that Light.
verses.freshTranslation: He himself was not the Light — but he was sent to testify about the Light.
verses.historicalContext: John the author says it twice in two verses: the Baptist is NOT the Light. This emphasis only makes sense if some readers might confuse the two. And they did — the Baptist had a massive following. Some thought HE was the Messiah (Luke 3:15). John the author is eliminating any ambiguity: the pointer is not the thing being pointed at.

crossRefs.explanation: The Baptist himself says: 'I am not the Christ, but I have been sent before Him... He must increase, but I must decrease.' The greatest humility statement in the Bible.
'The people were in expectation, and all were questioning in their hearts concerning John, whether he might be the Christ.' The confusion was real.

words.literalMeaning: not was that one
words.definition: Ouk — the strong Greek negative. Not maybe-not. Definitely not. Ekeinos — 'that one,' a distant demonstrative. John uses ekeinos to create distance between the Baptist and the Light — he wasn't even close to being the Light. The emphatic denial paired with the distant pronoun makes this as strong as Greek can make a 'no.'
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. The emphasis comes through.

words.partOfSpeech: noun with article, nominative neuter singular
words.literalMeaning: the Light
words.definition: THE Light — with the definite article. Not a light. Not some light. THE Light. The one from verses 4-5. The life of the Logos that illuminates humanity. There's only one. The Baptist could reflect it, but he could never BE it.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.english: but was sent to bear witness of that Light
words.original: ἀλλ' ἵνα μαρτυρήσῃ περὶ τοῦ φωτός
words.transliteration: all' hina martyrēsē peri tou phōtos
words.pronunciation: all HEE-nah mar-too-RAY-say peh-REE too foh-TOHS
words.literalMeaning: but in order that he might testify about the Light
words.definition: Alla — strong adversative conjunction. 'But' with force. Not just contrast — correction. 'He was NOT the Light — RATHER, he was sent to testify about it.' John redirects any misplaced attention from the Baptist to his actual function: witness. The greatest honor the Baptist had wasn't being great himself. It was pointing to someone greater.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

verses.verseText: That was the true Light which gives light to every man coming into the world.
verses.freshTranslation: The genuine Light — the one that illuminates every human being — was coming into the world.
verses.historicalContext: This verse has a grammatical ambiguity in Greek that changes the meaning significantly. Is 'coming into the world' describing the Light or describing every person? Most translations attach it to 'every man coming into the world' (= every person who is born). But in Greek, 'coming' (erchomenon) can also modify 'Light' — 'the true Light was coming into the world.' The second reading is more likely and more profound: the Light itself was entering the world. The incarnation is approaching.

crossRefs.explanation: Jesus says: 'I am the light of the world. Whoever follows me will not walk in darkness.' He claims to BE this true Light.
'As long as I am in the world, I am the light of the world.' The Light came into the world — and it has a time limit.
'I will make you as a light for the nations, that my salvation may reach to the end of the earth.' The universal scope of the Light was prophesied.

words.literalMeaning: was the Light the genuine/real one
words.definition: Alēthinon — genuine, real, authentic, the original as opposed to copies. NOT alēthēs (truthful/honest) but alēthinon (the real deal vs imitations). There are many lights in the world — prophets, teachers, philosophies, religions. They're lamps. This is the SUN. Alēthinon says: every other light you've encountered was a reflection or imitation. THIS is the source. The real one. The original that all others are shadows of. John the Baptist was a lamp (John 5:35). Jesus is the alēthinon phōs — the genuine, original, ultimate Light.
words.translationNote: 'True' is okay but in English 'true' usually means 'not false.' Alēthinon means more than 'not false' — it means 'the genuine article, the real thing, the original from which all copies derive.' 'Genuine' or 'authentic' would be better translations.
words.twistedExplanation: Translating alēthinon as 'true' makes readers think 'as opposed to false.' The real meaning is 'as opposed to derivative/secondary.' The Baptist was a real light — he wasn't false. But he wasn't the GENUINE, ORIGINAL light. There's a difference between something being fake and something being a copy of the original. Alēthinon distinguishes originals from copies, not truth from lies.

words.english: which gives light to every man
words.partOfSpeech: relative pronoun + verb present + adjective + noun
words.literalMeaning: which illuminates every human being
words.definition: Phōtizei — present tense, active voice. The Light ACTIVELY illuminates. It's not passive light sitting there waiting to be noticed. It goes out and illuminates. And panta anthrōpon — EVERY human. Universal. This means every person who has ever lived — whether they've heard the gospel or not — has been touched by this Light. This is the basis for general revelation, conscience, the sense of right and wrong, the perception of beauty. Romans 1:19-20 says the same thing: God has made Himself evident to all people through creation. The Light reaches everyone. Not everyone opens their eyes.
words.translationNote: 'Gives light to' is accurate but slightly passive. Phōtizei is more active — 'illuminates,' 'lights up,' 'floods with light.'

words.literalMeaning: coming into the world/ordered system
words.definition: Erchomenon — present participle of erchomai, 'coming.' Kosmon — world, ordered system, the created order. This is the first mention of kosmos in John — a word he'll use 78 times in this gospel. The Light was COMING into the kosmos. The eternal Logos was entering the created order. The uncreated was about to become part of creation. This is the prologue's countdown to verse 14 — the incarnation. Each verse gets closer: He was with God (v.1) → He made everything (v.3) → He is life and light (v.4) → He's coming into the world (v.9) → He was IN the world (v.10) → He BECAME flesh (v.14).
words.translationNote: The ambiguity of what 'coming' modifies (the Light or every person) is a real translation challenge. Most likely it modifies the Light — 'the genuine Light that illuminates every person was coming into the world.' The KJV attaches it to 'every man coming into the world' which works but misses the incarnation reference.
words.twistedExplanation: The KJV rendering 'every man that cometh into the world' (attaching 'coming' to man instead of Light) has been the dominant reading for centuries. But most modern scholars agree erchomenon modifies phōs (the Light), not anthrōpon (man). This changes the verse from a statement about human birth to a statement about the incarnation — the Light ITSELF was entering the world. That's a much bigger claim.

verses.verseText: He was in the world, and the world was made through Him, and the world did not know Him.
verses.freshTranslation: He was present in the world — the very world that came into existence through Him — and the world did not recognize Him.
verses.historicalContext: Three uses of 'world' (kosmos) in one verse, each with a different nuance. John is building a tragic irony: the Creator entered His own creation, and the creation didn't recognize its maker. Imagine an architect walking into a building he designed, and the building not knowing who he is. That's the scale of the tragedy John is describing.

crossRefs.explanation: 'All things were created through Him and for Him. He is before all things, and in Him all things hold together.' The world is held together by the one it rejected.
'He was despised and rejected by men, a man of sorrows and acquainted with grief.' Isaiah prophesied the rejection 700 years earlier.

words.literalMeaning: in the world He was existing
words.definition: Again ēn — imperfect, continuous existence. He wasn't just visiting. He was continually present in the world. Some scholars see this as referring to the pre-incarnate presence of the Logos in creation — He was always here, sustaining everything, even before Bethlehem. The world didn't suddenly gain His presence at the incarnation. It always had it. It just didn't know.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.english: and the world was made through Him
words.original: καὶ ὁ κόσμος δι' αὐτοῦ ἐγένετο
words.transliteration: kai ho kosmos di autou egeneto
words.pronunciation: kai ho KOS-mos dee ow-TOO eh-GHEH-neh-toh
words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + noun + preposition + pronoun + verb aorist
words.literalMeaning: and the world through Him came into being
words.definition: Egeneto again — the world CAME INTO BEING through Him. The world is a created thing (egeneto). He is the uncreated creator (ēn). And now the created thing doesn't recognize its creator. This is the setup for the most painful statement: He made it, He was in it, and it was blind to Him.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.english: and the world did not know Him
words.original: καὶ ὁ κόσμος αὐτὸν οὐκ ἔγνω
words.transliteration: kai ho kosmos auton ouk egnō
words.pronunciation: kai ho KOS-mos ow-TON ook EHG-noh
words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + noun + pronoun + negative + verb aorist
words.literalMeaning: and the world Him did not know/recognize
words.definition: Egnō — from ginōskō, to know experientially, to recognize, to perceive. This is relational knowledge, not intellectual. The world didn't RECOGNIZE Him. It's not that they lacked information — creation itself declares God's glory (Psalm 19:1). They had the data. They didn't have the recognition. Like a child who doesn't recognize their father in a crowd. The information is there. The connection isn't made. The world's failure wasn't intellectual but relational — it didn't KNOW its maker in the intimate, ginōskō sense.
words.translationNote: 'Know' is accurate but in English can sound purely intellectual. Ginōskō is experiential recognition — not 'they didn't know facts about Him' but 'they didn't recognize Him when He was standing right in front of them.'

verses.verseText: He came to His own, and His own did not receive Him.
verses.freshTranslation: He came to His own home — to His own people — and His own people did not welcome Him in.
verses.historicalContext: This is the most painful verse in the prologue. 'His own' (ta idia) means His own property, His own home. Israel was God's chosen people — His inheritance, His vineyard (Isaiah 5), His firstborn son (Exodus 4:22). The Logos came HOME. And home rejected Him. This is personal. This isn't the ignorant world not recognizing a stranger. This is family refusing to open the door.

crossRefs.explanation: Jesus weeps: 'O Jerusalem, Jerusalem... how often I wanted to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were not willing!' The rejection was willful, not accidental.
God planted a vineyard (Israel), built a wall around it, expected good grapes, and got wild ones. The parable of rejected love.
'Israel is My firstborn son.' Israel wasn't just a nation — it was God's family. The rejection is familial.

words.partOfSpeech: preposition + adjective neuter plural + verb aorist
words.literalMeaning: to His own things/home/property He came
words.definition: Ta idia — neuter plural of idios, meaning 'one's own things, one's own home, one's own property.' This is the word for personal belongings, your own house, your own territory. John 19:27 uses the same phrase when John took Mary 'to his own home' (eis ta idia). The Logos came to HIS OWN HOME. The world was His creation. Israel was His people. The Temple was His house. He came home. And home didn't want Him.
words.translationNote: 'His own' is vague in English. The Greek specifies: His own HOME, His own PROPERTY. It's not just 'His own people' — it's His own place, His own domain. He came to where He belonged.

words.english: and His own did not receive Him
words.original: καὶ οἱ ἴδιοι αὐτὸν οὐ παρέλαβον
words.transliteration: kai hoi idioi auton ou parelabon
words.pronunciation: kai hoy EE-dee-oy ow-TON oo pah-REH-lah-bon
words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + adjective masculine plural + pronoun + negative + verb aorist
words.literalMeaning: and His own people Him did not receive/welcome alongside
words.definition: Notice the shift: ta idia (neuter — His own THINGS/home) becomes hoi idioi (masculine — His own PEOPLE). He came to His place; His people rejected Him. Parelabon — from paralambanō — to receive alongside, to welcome, to take to oneself. It implies hospitality — taking someone into your home, into your life. They didn't just fail to recognize Him (like the world in v.10). They actively refused to receive Him. Recognition vs reception — the world was blind; Israel was unwilling. That's worse.
words.translationNote: 'Receive' captures parelabon adequately, but the shift from neuter 'His own' (home/property) to masculine 'His own' (people) is invisible in English. It's the same phrase in English but different genders in Greek, making two distinct points.
words.twistedExplanation: English can't show the neuter→masculine shift. In verse 11a, 'His own' is neuter (ta idia = His own home/domain). In verse 11b, 'His own' is masculine (hoi idioi = His own people). The English reads like repetition. The Greek reads like escalation: His home → His family. The rejection gets more personal with each word.

verses.verseText: But as many as received Him, to them He gave the right to become children of God, to those who believe in His name:
verses.freshTranslation: But to everyone who did receive Him — who trusted in His name — He gave the authority to become born ones of God.
verses.historicalContext: After the devastating rejection of verses 10-11, John pivots with 'but' (de). Not everyone rejected Him. Some received Him. And to those who did, something unprecedented happened: they were authorized to become God's children. In the Old Testament, Israel was God's 'son' collectively (Exodus 4:22). But individual humans becoming 'children of God' through the Logos — that's new. That's the new covenant.

crossRefs.explanation: Paul expands this: 'For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, these are sons of God... The Spirit Himself bears witness with our spirit that we are children of God.'
'For you are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus.' The mechanism is faith/trust, exactly as John says.
Same author, overwhelmed by the same truth: 'See what great love the Father has lavished on us, that we should be called children of God! And that is what we are!'

words.english: But as many as received Him
words.partOfSpeech: relative pronoun + conjunction + verb aorist + pronoun
words.literalMeaning: as many as however received/took Him
words.definition: Hosoi — 'as many as,' 'whoever,' 'everyone who.' No restriction. No ethnic requirement. No prerequisite. Whoever. De — mild adversative, 'but/however.' Elabon — from lambanō, to receive, to take, to grasp. This is the positive counterpart to parelabon in verse 11. Israel didn't paralambanō (welcome alongside). But whoever DID lambanō (receive, grasp) Him got something extraordinary.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.english: to them He gave the right
words.literalMeaning: He gave to them authority/right/power
words.definition: Exousia — this word is HUGE. It means authority, right, power, permission, liberty. It's not just a legal right like a certificate. It's actual authority — delegated power. The same word used when Jesus 'gave them authority (exousia) over unclean spirits' (Matthew 10:1). God doesn't just permit you to be His child. He gives you the AUTHORITY of a child — the status, the access, the inheritance, the family name. Exousia includes the power to actually become what you're authorized to be.
words.translationNote: 'Right' is okay but weak. Exousia means authorized power, not just permission. 'Authority' is better. You don't just have permission to call God Father — you have the delegated authority of a son or daughter.
words.twistedExplanation: Translating exousia as 'right' domesticates it. In English, a 'right' is passive — something you're allowed to do. Exousia is active — it's the power and authority to do it. You don't just have the right to become God's child. You have been given the authority, the power, the divine backing to actually become one. That's a much bigger statement.

words.partOfSpeech: noun + noun genitive + verb aorist infinitive
words.literalMeaning: born-ones of God to become
words.definition: Tekna — not huioi (sons) but tekna — 'born ones,' 'offspring,' children in the sense of being BORN from a parent. The word emphasizes origin — where you came from. And genesthai — from ginomai, to become. Not 'to be declared' children of God. To BECOME them. Something actually changes. You become something you weren't before. This isn't a title change. It's a nature change. And it connects directly to verse 13 — which explains HOW this birth happens.
words.translationNote: 'Children' is accurate for tekna. The key nuance is that tekna emphasizes birth/origin while huioi emphasizes status/position. John chose the birth word — you're not adopted into a legal position (Paul uses huioi for that). You're BORN into a family. Different metaphor, different emphasis.

words.english: to those who believe in His name
words.original: τοῖς πιστεύουσιν εἰς τὸ ὄνομα αὐτοῦ
words.transliteration: tois pisteuousin eis to onoma autou
words.pronunciation: toys pis-TYOO-oo-sin ace toh OH-no-mah ow-TOO
words.partOfSpeech: article + participle present + preposition + noun + pronoun
words.literalMeaning: to the ones trusting into the name of Him
words.definition: Pisteuousin — present participle of pisteuō. Present tense means ongoing, continuous trust — not a one-time decision but a continuing state of trust. Eis to onoma — 'into the name.' Not just believing ABOUT His name or THAT His name is real. Believing INTO it — entering into it, investing yourself in it. In Hebrew thought, a name (שֵׁם / shem) IS the person — their character, reputation, authority, essence. To believe 'into His name' means to entrust yourself to everything He is.
words.translationNote: 'Believe in' flattens the Greek. The preposition eis (into) with pisteuō implies movement — you're not just believing about something from the outside. You're trusting yourself INTO something. Committing. Entering in.
words.twistedExplanation: 'Believe in' has become a passive phrase in English — 'I believe in Santa Claus' and 'I believe in Jesus' sound grammatically identical. But pisteuō eis is active, directional, and total — it means to place your whole trust INTO someone, to commit yourself to them. The English phrasing makes salvation sound like a mental checkbox. The Greek makes it sound like jumping off a cliff into someone's arms.

verses.verseText: who were born, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God.
verses.freshTranslation: These ones were born — not from bloodline, not from physical desire, not from a husband's decision — but from God Himself.
verses.historicalContext: John lists three things that do NOT produce spiritual birth, then names the one thing that does. This was revolutionary for a Jewish audience: being born into the right bloodline (Abraham's descendants) doesn't make you God's child. Physical descent is irrelevant to spiritual birth. John the Baptist said the same thing: 'Do not think to say to yourselves, we have Abraham as our father' (Matthew 3:9). The new birth isn't genetic. It's from God.

crossRefs.explanation: Jesus tells Nicodemus: 'Unless one is born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God... That which is born of the flesh is flesh, and that which is born of the Spirit is spirit.' Verse 13 is the thesis; John 3 is the explanation.
John the Baptist: 'Do not think to say, We have Abraham as our father. For I tell you, God is able from these stones to raise up children for Abraham.' Bloodline doesn't equal sonship.
Paul makes the same point: 'Not all who are descended from Israel belong to Israel... it is not the children of the flesh who are the children of God, but the children of the promise.'

words.partOfSpeech: relative pronoun + verb, aorist passive indicative, 3rd person plural
words.literalMeaning: who were begotten/generated/born
words.definition: Gennaō — to beget, to give birth, to generate. Passive voice — they were born BY someone else. They didn't birth themselves. This is God's action, not human effort. You don't generate your own spiritual birth any more than you chose to be physically born. Someone else did that to you.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.literalMeaning: not out of bloods (plural)
words.definition: Haimatōn — bloods, PLURAL. This is unusual. 'Bloods' in Hebrew idiom refers to bloodline — the mixing of parents' blood to produce offspring. It's about genetic descent, family lineage, ethnic heritage. Being Jewish by birth. Having Abraham's DNA. John says: that's not how you become God's child. Your family tree is irrelevant to your spiritual birth. This destroyed the primary Jewish assumption about covenant membership.
words.translationNote: Most translations say 'blood' (singular) when the Greek is clearly plural 'bloods' (haimatōn). The plural points specifically to lineage/descent — the mixing of two parents' blood. 'Bloodline' would be more accurate than 'blood.'
words.twistedExplanation: Changing the plural 'bloods' to singular 'blood' hides the specific meaning. 'Not of blood' sounds vague and mysterious. 'Not of bloods' (or 'not of bloodlines') clearly means genetic descent and family heritage don't produce spiritual birth. The plural is theologically precise; the singular translation is theologically fuzzy.

words.english: nor of the will of the flesh
words.partOfSpeech: negative + preposition + noun genitive + noun genitive
words.literalMeaning: nor out of the will/desire of flesh
words.definition: Thelēma — will, desire, wish, determination. Sarx — flesh, the physical body, human nature in its weakness. The 'will of the flesh' is physical/sexual desire — the natural human drive to reproduce. You can't produce spiritual children through physical means. No amount of human effort, religious ritual, or physical action generates spiritual birth. It's not something your body does.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated, though 'will of the flesh' sounds abstract. It specifically means human sexual/reproductive desire — you can't birth yourself into God's family through physical procreation.

words.english: nor of the will of man
words.partOfSpeech: negative + preposition + noun genitive + noun genitive
words.literalMeaning: nor out of the will/decision of a husband/man
words.definition: NOW John uses anēr (andros) — a male, specifically a husband — NOT anthrōpos (generic human). This is deliberate. In the ancient world, the husband decided to have children. It was the patriarch's decision to produce an heir. John says: a man's decision to have children doesn't produce children of God. No human authority figure — no father, no priest, no rabbi, no pastor — can decide to make you God's child. That authority belongs to God alone.
words.translationNote: 'Man' hides the specificity. Anēr means 'male/husband' specifically. This isn't repeating 'flesh' — it's adding a new layer. Flesh = physical desire. Anēr = a husband's deliberate decision. Neither works. Only God's action works.
words.twistedExplanation: Translating anēr as 'man' (generic) instead of 'husband' or 'male' hides John's progression: bloods (lineage) → flesh (physical desire) → husband (male authority/decision). Three layers of human reproduction, all negated. The English makes it sound like two vague repetitions. The Greek is a precise, escalating denial of every human mechanism for producing spiritual life.

words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + preposition + noun genitive + verb aorist passive
words.literalMeaning: but out of God they were born/begotten
words.definition: Alla — the strong adversative again. After three 'not from's, one thundering 'BUT FROM.' Ek theou — out of God, from God as the source. God is the origin of the new birth. Not your bloodline, not your body, not your husband, not your pastor, not your own decision ultimately — GOD. He begets. You are begotten. The passive voice (egennēthēsan — 'they were born') means you don't do the birthing. You receive it. Just like your physical birth wasn't your idea or your effort, your spiritual birth originates with God.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. The force of the alla (but) after three negations is powerful even in English.

verses.verseText: And the Word became flesh and dwelt among us, and we beheld His glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father, full of grace and truth.
verses.freshTranslation: And the Word became flesh — became human — and pitched His tent among us. We gazed upon His glory — glory like that of a Father's one and only Son — overflowing with grace and truth.
verses.historicalContext: THIS IS IT. This is the verse the entire prologue has been building toward. The eternal Logos — who was with God, who was God, who made everything — became sarx. Flesh. Meat. The most physical, earthy, unglamorous word John could have chosen. Not 'became human' (anthrōpos) or 'took on a body' (sōma). FLESH. The stuff that bleeds and sweats and gets hungry and tired and dies. The infinite became finite. The Creator became a creature. The uncreated Word that spoke galaxies into existence became a baby who needed His mother to feed Him. This is the most staggering claim in all of religious literature. No other religion makes this claim — that God didn't just VISIT humanity but BECAME human. 'Dwelt among us' is literally 'tabernacled among us' — eskēnōsen — He pitched His tent, echoing the tabernacle in the wilderness where God's presence dwelt with Israel. God is camping with humanity again.

crossRefs.explanation: 'Let them make me a sanctuary, that I may dwell (שָׁכַן / shakan) among them.' The tabernacle was God's tent among His people. John says Jesus IS the new tabernacle — God's presence dwelling in human flesh.
Moses asked to see God's glory. God said 'you cannot see my face and live' and showed only His back. Now the glory LIVES among us in flesh. What Moses could only glimpse, John says 'we beheld.'

Paul describes the same event: 'Who, being in the form of God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped, but emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men.'
'Great indeed is the mystery of godliness: God was manifested in the flesh.' The early church creed, saying the same thing John says.
'For in Him the whole fullness of deity dwells bodily.' All of God, in a body. That's verse 14 in one sentence.

words.literalMeaning: and the Word/Logos
words.definition: The same Logos from verse 1. The one who was in the beginning. The one who was face-to-face with God. The one who WAS God. The one through whom everything was made. That Logos. John brings us full circle — you know who He is now. You've spent 13 verses learning about His eternity, His divinity, His creative power. Now watch what He does.
words.translationNote: See verse 1 notes on logos.

words.partOfSpeech: verb, aorist middle indicative, 3rd person singular
words.literalMeaning: became, came into being as
words.definition: The most shocking use of egeneto in the Bible. In verse 1, the Word ĒN (was — eternally existing). In verse 3, everything else EGENETO (came into being — was created). Now the Word Himself EGENETO — became something He wasn't before. The eternal entered time. The uncreated took on created nature. This isn't saying the Word was REPLACED by flesh or TURNED INTO flesh. It's saying the Word ADDED flesh to Himself. He didn't stop being the Logos. He became the Logos-in-flesh. Both natures. One person. This single word is the foundation of everything Christians believe about the incarnation.
words.translationNote: 'Became' is accurate and the best English can do. The weight of egeneto here — the same verb used for creation in verse 3 now applied to the Creator Himself — is staggering but impossible to convey in translation without a footnote.

words.literalMeaning: flesh, meat, the physical body, human nature in its weakness and mortality
words.definition: John didn't say the Word became anthrōpos (a human) or sōma (a body) or morphē (a form). He said SARX — flesh. Raw, physical, vulnerable, mortal flesh. This is the most visceral, physical, unglamorous word available. Sarx is meat. It's what you see at a butcher shop. It bleeds, bruises, breaks, and dies. John chose this word ON PURPOSE to combat the Gnostic heresy that Jesus only APPEARED to be human (docetism). No — He became SARX. Real flesh. Real blood. Real hunger, real thirst, real pain, real death. The God who holds galaxies together had a belly button. That's sarx.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. 'Flesh' in English still carries the right rawness. Some modern translations soften it to 'human' or 'human being' which loses the shock value John intended. He WANTED it to be jarring.

words.literalMeaning: and tabernacled/pitched-tent in/among us
words.definition: Skēnoō — to pitch a tent, to tabernacle, to set up camp. From skēnē — a tent. This is a MASSIVE allusion to the Old Testament. The tabernacle (mishkan / מִשְׁכָּן in Hebrew, from shakan / שָׁכַן — to dwell) was the portable tent where God's glory-presence dwelt among Israel in the wilderness. The Shekinah (שְׁכִינָה) — the visible glory of God — filled the tabernacle (Exodus 40:34). John is saying: Jesus IS the new tabernacle. God's glory-presence isn't in a tent made of animal skins anymore. It's in FLESH. The Greek skēnoō even SOUNDS like the Hebrew shakan. John is almost certainly making a deliberate phonetic connection between the two languages for his bilingual audience.
words.translationNote: 'Dwelt' is severely inadequate. It's technically not wrong but it completely hides the tabernacle connection. 'Tabernacled among us' or 'pitched His tent among us' would preserve the most important allusion in the verse. Every Jew reading this in Greek would have heard the echo of the mishkan. English readers miss it entirely.
words.twistedExplanation: Translating eskēnōsen as simply 'dwelt' is one of the biggest losses in Bible translation. The word means 'tabernacled' — it directly connects Jesus to the OT tabernacle where God's presence lived among Israel. The entire theology of God's presence moving from tent → temple → flesh → believers is encoded in this one verb. 'Dwelt' erases all of it. Every reader should know this word means 'pitched His tent' — God went camping with humanity.

words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + verb aorist middle + article + noun + pronoun
words.literalMeaning: and we gazed upon/contemplated the glory of Him
words.definition: Theaomai — not just 'see' (blepō) or 'look at' (horaō). Theaomai means to gaze at with wonder, to contemplate, to behold something spectacular. It's where we get 'theater' — a place of spectacle and viewing. John isn't saying 'we noticed Him.' He's saying 'we couldn't stop staring.' We GAZED at His glory. And doxa — glory, magnificence, splendor, the visible manifestation of God's nature. The same doxa that filled the tabernacle (Exodus 40:34), that Moses begged to see (Exodus 33:18), that was too intense for humans to survive — John says 'we beheld it.' In a human face. In flesh.
words.translationNote: 'Beheld' is decent — it's more elevated than 'saw.' But 'gazed upon' or 'contemplated' would better capture theaomai's sense of prolonged, awestruck observation. This wasn't a glance. It was a stare.

words.english: the glory as of the only begotten of the Father
words.partOfSpeech: noun + conjunction + adjective genitive + preposition + noun genitive
words.literalMeaning: glory as of an only-one-of-its-kind from-beside a Father
words.definition: Monogenēs — THIS WORD. It does NOT mean 'only begotten' in the sense of 'created' or 'born.' It comes from monos (only) + genos (kind, type, class) — meaning 'one of a kind, unique, the only one of its type.' The older derivation from gennaō (to beget) has been corrected by modern scholarship. Monogenēs means unique, not procreated. Isaac was called Abraham's monogenēs (Hebrews 11:17) even though Abraham had other sons (Ishmael). Isaac was the unique one — the promised one, the one-of-a-kind. Jesus isn't God's Son because God 'begat' Him in time. He's monogenēs — the utterly unique, one-of-a-kind Son. There is no other like Him. Para patros — 'from beside a Father' — the same intimate para from verse 6. From the Father's side.
words.translationNote: 'Only begotten' is a famously problematic translation. It implies the Son was 'begotten' or produced at some point in time, which contradicts verse 1 (the Word was ALREADY existing in the beginning). Modern translations increasingly use 'only,' 'one and only,' or 'unique' — which is what monogenēs actually means. The KJV's 'only begotten' has caused centuries of theological confusion.
words.twistedExplanation: 'Only begotten' (KJV) led to the Arian heresy and Jehovah's Witness theology — the idea that the Son was 'begotten' (created/produced) by the Father at some point. But monogenēs means 'one-of-a-kind,' not 'only-produced.' The Son is unique, not manufactured. This single mistranslation has fueled more theological error than almost any other word in the Bible. Modern scholarship overwhelmingly supports 'one and only' or 'unique' as the correct translation.

words.partOfSpeech: adjective + noun genitive + conjunction + noun genitive
words.literalMeaning: full/complete of grace/unmerited-favor and truth/reality
words.definition: Plērēs — full, complete, lacking nothing. Not 'containing some grace.' FULL of it. Overflowing. Charis — grace, unmerited favor, the free gift of God's goodness that you didn't earn and can't repay. This is the first use of charis in John's gospel — and he saves it for the incarnation. Grace doesn't appear in the abstract. It appears in flesh. Alētheia — truth, reality, what is genuinely real. Not just 'correct information' but reality itself as opposed to illusion. Together, charis kai alētheia echoes the Old Testament description of God: חֶסֶד וֶאֱמֶת (chesed ve'emet) — lovingkindness and faithfulness (Exodus 34:6). When God revealed His character to Moses, He described Himself as 'abounding in chesed and emet.' John is saying: that same God — that same character — is now visible in flesh.
words.translationNote: 'Grace and truth' is accurate. The OT connection to chesed ve'emet (lovingkindness and faithfulness) from Exodus 34:6 is crucial — John is declaring that Jesus is the embodiment of God's self-described character. What God said about Himself to Moses is now walking around in sandals.

verses.verseText: John bore witness of Him and cried out, saying, "This was He of whom I said, 'He who comes after me is preferred before me, for He was before me.'"
verses.freshTranslation: John testified about Him and shouted: 'This is the one I was talking about — the one coming after me has been placed ahead of me, because He existed before me.'
verses.historicalContext: John the Baptist was physically OLDER than Jesus by about six months (Luke 1:26, 36). So when he says 'He was before me,' he can't mean chronologically in human terms. He means in a deeper sense — the Logos existed before the Baptist, before Abraham, before creation. The Baptist is claiming that the man standing in front of him — his younger cousin — is the pre-existent God.

crossRefs.explanation: Jesus Himself claims this: 'Before Abraham was, I AM (egō eimi).' The same pre-existence the Baptist recognized.
'He is before all things.' Not just before John. Before everything.

words.english: John bore witness of Him and cried out
words.original: Ἰωάννης μαρτυρεῖ περὶ αὐτοῦ καὶ κέκραγεν
words.transliteration: Iōannēs martyrei peri autou kai kekragen
words.pronunciation: ee-oh-AH-nays mar-too-RAY peh-REE ow-TOO kai KEH-krah-ghen
words.partOfSpeech: noun + verb present + preposition + pronoun + conjunction + verb perfect
words.literalMeaning: John testifies about Him and has cried out
words.definition: Martyrei — present tense! John's testimony is ongoing, still active, still speaking through the record. And kekragen — perfect tense of krazō — to cry out, to shout, to scream. Perfect tense means he cried out in the past and the cry is still echoing. Krazō isn't polite speaking. It's shouting. The Baptist wasn't casually mentioning Jesus. He was screaming at people to pay attention. This is a street preacher level of urgency.
words.translationNote: 'Bore witness' (past tense) misses the present tense in Greek — John's testimony is treated as ongoing. 'Cried out' is good — krazō is loud and urgent.

words.english: He who comes after me is preferred before me
words.original: ὁ ὀπίσω μου ἐρχόμενος ἔμπροσθέν μου γέγονεν
words.transliteration: ho opisō mou erchomenos emprosthen mou gegonen
words.pronunciation: ho oh-PEE-soh moo er-KHO-meh-nos EM-pros-then moo GHEH-go-nen
words.partOfSpeech: article + adverb + pronoun + participle + adverb + pronoun + verb perfect
words.literalMeaning: the one after me coming has become/been placed before me
words.definition: Opisō mou — 'after me' (in time, in ministry order). The Baptist started his ministry first. Jesus came after. But emprosthen mou — 'before me, ahead of me' — in rank, in importance, in position. Gegonen — perfect tense of ginomai — 'has become' or 'has been placed.' He has taken the position ahead. The one who came later in time holds the higher position. Because...
words.translationNote: 'Preferred before me' (KJV) sounds like a personal preference. The Greek means He has been RANKED ahead, placed in front. It's positional authority, not preference.

words.literalMeaning: because first/before me He was existing
words.definition: Prōtos — first, before, chief. And ĒN — that same imperfect verb from verse 1. He WAS ALREADY EXISTING before me. Not egeneto (came into being before me) but ēn (was continually existing before me). The Baptist, speaking about his younger cousin, uses the verb reserved for eternal pre-existence. He knows exactly who Jesus is. A man born six months after the Baptist — but who existed before the universe.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated. The force of ēn (eternal pre-existence) vs potential egeneto (created before) is critical but invisible in English 'was.'

verses.verseText: And of His fullness we have all received, and grace for grace.
verses.freshTranslation: Out of His fullness we have all received — grace upon grace, one wave of grace replacing the last.
verses.historicalContext: John shifts from the Baptist's testimony back to his own first-person reflection. 'We have all received' — John includes himself and all believers. The image is of an inexhaustible supply — you take from His fullness and it doesn't diminish. Like an ocean you can't empty.

crossRefs.explanation: 'For it pleased the Father that in Him all the fullness (plērōma) should dwell.' The same concept — Jesus contains the totality of God's being.
Paul prays believers would 'be filled with all the fullness (plērōma) of God.' What's in Christ flows into His people.
'And you are complete (filled up) in Him.' Believers share in the fullness.

words.literalMeaning: because out of the fullness of Him
words.definition: Plērōma — fullness, completeness, the total sum of everything. From plēroō — to fill completely. This was a loaded term in John's world. Gnostic philosophers used plērōma to describe the totality of divine powers. John hijacks their word: the plērōma isn't a complex system of emanations. It's all in ONE person — Jesus. Everything God is, everything God has, the total package — that's the plērōma and it lives in the Word-made-flesh. And ek — out of. We receive OUT OF His fullness. It flows from Him to us.
words.translationNote: 'Fullness' captures plērōma well. The word is rich and technical but 'fullness' conveys the core meaning.

words.literalMeaning: we all received/took
words.definition: Hēmeis pantes — WE ALL. John includes everyone. Elabomen — from lambanō, to receive. Same root as verse 12 where those who 'received Him' got the authority to become children of God. Those who received Him then received FROM His fullness. The receiving doesn't stop at the initial acceptance. It continues — you keep drawing from the supply.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.literalMeaning: and grace in place of / upon / in exchange for grace
words.definition: Anti — this preposition is debated. It can mean (1) 'in place of' — new grace replacing old grace, like waves on a beach, one replacing the next; (2) 'upon' — grace piled on grace; (3) 'in exchange for' — grace received in response to grace. Most likely meaning: wave after wave of grace, each one replacing the last. Like ocean waves — the moment one grace recedes, the next one arrives. It never stops. You don't get one serving of grace and that's it. It's continuous, relentless, unending. The image is of overwhelming, excessive, never-ending generosity from God.
words.translationNote: 'Grace for grace' is literal but cryptic. Most modern readers have no idea what it means. 'Grace upon grace' (ESV/NIV) is better. 'One wave of grace after another' captures the dynamic, unending quality John is describing.
words.twistedExplanation: The KJV 'grace for grace' is so cryptic it's almost meaningless to modern readers. Anti charitos is a beautiful image — grace replacing grace, like waves — that gets lost in overly literal translation. 'Grace upon grace' or 'grace after grace' would serve readers far better.

verses.verseText: For the law was given through Moses, but grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.
verses.freshTranslation: For the law was given through Moses — but grace and truth arrived through Jesus the Messiah.
verses.historicalContext: THIS is the first time Jesus is named in John's gospel. Seventeen verses of building up — Logos, God, Creator, life, light, flesh, glory — and NOW John drops the name: Jesus Christ. Iēsous Christos. The reveal. Everything you've been reading about? His name is Jesus. And John sets up a deliberate contrast: Moses brought the law (a good thing — given by God). But Jesus brought something greater: grace AND truth — the embodiment of chesed ve'emet (Exodus 34:6). The law told you what God required. Jesus IS what God is like.

crossRefs.explanation: God's self-description to Moses: 'Abounding in chesed (lovingkindness) and emet (faithfulness/truth).' John says this same pair — grace and truth — came through Jesus. Moses heard God describe Himself. Jesus IS that description in person.
'You are not under law but under grace.' Paul makes the same Moses→Jesus, law→grace transition.
'Jesus has been counted worthy of more glory than Moses.' Greater than the greatest prophet.

words.english: For the law was given through Moses
words.original: ὅτι ὁ νόμος διὰ Μωϋσέως ἐδόθη
words.transliteration: hoti ho nomos dia Mōyseōs edothē
words.pronunciation: HOH-tee ho NO-mos dee-AH mo-oo-SEH-ohs eh-DOH-thay
words.partOfSpeech: conjunction + noun + preposition + proper noun + verb aorist passive
words.literalMeaning: because the law through Moses was given
words.definition: Nomos — law, regulation, principle. Specifically the Torah — the law of Moses. Dia Mōyseōs — through Moses as the agent. Edothē — passive of didōmi (to give). The law was GIVEN — passive voice — meaning God gave it THROUGH Moses. Moses was the delivery system, not the source. And John isn't dismissing the law — he says it was 'given,' which is a positive word. The law was a gift. But it was an incomplete gift. It told you what righteousness looked like but couldn't make you righteous.
words.translationNote: Accurately translated.

words.english: but grace and truth came through Jesus Christ
words.original: ἡ χάρις καὶ ἡ ἀλήθεια διὰ Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ ἐγένετο
words.transliteration: hē charis kai hē alētheia dia Iēsou Christou egeneto
words.pronunciation: hay KAH-ris kai hay ah-LAY-thay-ah dee-AH ee-ay-SOO khris-TOO eh-GHEH-neh-toh
words.partOfSpeech: noun + conjunction + noun + preposition + proper noun + verb aorist
words.literalMeaning: the grace and the truth through Jesus Christ came into being
words.definition: The law was 'given' (edothē). Grace and truth 'came into being' (egeneto) — they arrived, they materialized, they became real and present. Not just communicated from a distance like the law on tablets. Grace and truth showed up in person. Iēsous — the Greek form of Hebrew Yehoshua (יְהוֹשֻׁעַ) or shortened Yeshua (יֵשׁוּעַ), meaning 'Yahweh saves' or 'Yahweh is salvation.' His name is His mission. Christos — from chriō, to anoint. The Greek equivalent of Hebrew Mashiach (מָשִׁיחַ) — Messiah, the Anointed One. After 17 verses of cosmic theology, John finally says the name: Jesus the Messiah. The Logos has a human name.
